document.text: The Evans and Nash Construction Company, of Appomattox, has been awarded, a contract on a low bid of 24,960.6, for the construc tion- of a flood water retarding structure, Site 15, in the East Fork Falling River Pilot Watershed, this county. The announcement was made yesterday in Richmond. Work is ex pected to begin in 30 days. This is the first of three such pro jects to be undertaken in Appomat tox County. Bids for Site 21 will be opened next month. The Pilot Watershed protection program comprises about 34,000 acres in Appomattox and Campbell Counties. The site of the first work is about three miles northeast of the Town of Appomattox. W oic on the first project will consume about three months. Robert E. Lee Soil Conservation District is sponsor of the project. The project is designed to show what can be done with such a pro gram as a method of flood damage reduction and soil and water con servation within a small watershed. A dam will be so constructed that there will be a normal flow of wa ter when the season is normal. When heavy rains come, the flow of water below the dam will be only slightly accelerated and the area back of the dam will act as storage and let through overflow pipes at a slow rate of speed.

Capt. J. V. Henry, former assistant postmaster at Quincy, 111., was arrested on the charge of embezzlement from the National Railway Mail Service Benevolent Association. Theodore Furley was sentenced to 15 years in the penitentiary for attempted rape on Mrs. Sarah Bowers, near Darkeville, W. Va. The threatened race riot at George town, 8. C., was averted by the Gov ernor, who ordered the dispensary and beer privilege closed. President John E. Hudson, of the American Bell Telephone Company, DW suddenly in a railroad station in Beverly, Mass. A crowded trolley car ran away in Wichita, Kan., throwing 50 paasengers into a creek, of whom 30 were injured. Mrs. Frank Leslie retired from the management of Leslies Popular Monthly. General Colton Green, an ex-Con- federate, died at his home in Memphis. Tenn. A severed human head was found in a grain sack in Cedar Lake, Ind. Rev. Young Reeder, pastor of the Columbia S. C. Baptist Church, who had been warned by an opposing faction not to hold services, was shot dead while praying, and Rev. B. H. Williams, who was assisting him, was wounded. Sexto Lopez, formerly secretary of Agulnaldo, arrived in New York on the Cunarder Campania to explain to the American people, he says, the Fili pinos side of their fight against the Americans. Harry Bloomburg, a traveling sales man, from Hagerstown, Md., was found unconscious on the mountain road near Franklin Furnace, Pa. He claim ed to have been a victim of knockout drops. In Frankfort, Ky., Judge Cantrell overruled the motion for a new trial made in behalf of James Howard, con vlcted of killing Governor Goebel, and sentenced him to be hanged. Notice of appeal was given. Tim Murray, who represented him self as collector of political contribu tlons for both parties, was sent to the penitentiary for one year in La Crosse, Wis. The Manchester Va. police chased through the wilds of Chesterfield on the scent of a man they believed to be Topeka Joe. Fire broke out on the steamer American at New Orleans in the com partment in which 35,000 bushels of wheat was stored. Settlement of the coal strike is still distant President Mitphell says the proposed offer of a 10 per cent, increase to the miners would be unsatisfactory, and it is probable that the strikers would reject it. Ileywood, of the Marine Corps, arrived at the Ports mouth Va. Navy Yard on his tour of inspection. Josiah R. Adams, a prominent law yer and clubman, of Philadelphia, com mitted suicide without apparent cause. Deputy Sheriff Sloan was killed at Lake Charles, La., while defending a negro prisoner from a mob. John B a lle n g e r, a farmer, residing near Mount Vernon, Fairfax county, Va., committed suicide. Prof. John E. Gintner, of the Otter- beln University, died at his home in Westerville, O. Warrants were issued in New York against big concerns for violating the smoke ordinance. document.text: St. Paul, Minn., Special. North Da kota and the Canadian Northwest are ex periencing the worst snowstorm in many years and railroad traffic is practically paralyzed. The Northern Pacific and Great Northern have not moved a wheel for nearly 31 hours in the blizzard-strick en district and have abandoned all efforts to run trains until the fury of the storm abates. The high wind has piled the snow in the mountains and packed it in solid masses, many deep cuts being entirely filled. The temperature has been grad ually falling and is now at or below the zero mark. Not a trans-continental train has arrived at St. Paul since Friday, and -none is expected for several days. Every effort is being made by the road to keep its passengers who are snowbound warm and well fed. For this reason trains are being held at stations where the accom modations are good rather than attempt to get them through, with a possibility of being tied up between stations. The Red River Valley division of the North ern Pacific between Frankfort and Win nipeg. Manitoba, has been entirely aban doned. The telegraph wires have been carried down by the burden of sleet that preceded the heavy snowfall. The Great Northern is tied tip entirely between Grand Forks and Williston, N. D., a distance of about 35 miles, and all wires have been lost beyond Fargo. All communication by wire with Western Dakota and Montana points has been lost. The branch of the Great Northern run ning to Winnipeg is also tied up. No trains have been started northward since Friday night, and those that were caught out on the road by the storm have been held at the station near the border. Winnipeg is reported entirely cut off from railroad communication with the outside world. The Canadian Pacific trans continental trains are snowbound somewhere west of there and no prospect of relief is yet in sight.

document.text: How Town Was Named. An Interesting story to told as to the origin of the name .Moose Jaw, as ap plied to a town in Canada. Some 60 years ago, so the story runs, a pioneer with his team of oxen and prairie schooner, while passing along the banks of the river, was obliged to camp at this point in Saskatchewan on account of an accident to his cart. A spoke had fallen out during the day, and the wheel was falling apart He looked about for something to In sert for a temporary brace fbr the  wheel, while his wife busied herself  with the evening meal. The pioneers child, while romping around, found the Jawbone of a moose, which she held up to her father, who by this time almost despaired of find ing anything with which to repair his cart He was delighted to find that the Jawbone exactly fitted the place of the missing spoke. The Indians thereafter named this district The Place Where the White Man Found the Moose Jaw. This, It Is said, accounts for the towns queer name.Washington Star.

document.text: HEN Pierre Fontaine mull Camille CliaQuette built their cabin on the bank of  the Beaver River, a trib-  utnry of the Upper George, in Northern Labrador, they looked forward confidently to a profita ble winter. Both had resigned only recently from the Hudson Bay Com panys corps of voyaguers, and this was to be their first season as independent trappers. Except for a few roving Montagnnis Indians, the district was quite uninhabited, but inured to soli tude, the hardy young hunters were not men to lament the dearth of neigh bors. Their store of pelts accumulated steadily. Early in the winter Pierre brought in a silver fox skin, and later Camille secured a black one. But skins of the marten predominated. It was, in fact, what trappers terra a marten year. Like the migratory car ibou and their faithful followers, the wolf paeks, these highly prized little animals oeeasionaliy forsake their reg ular habitat. Years, during which few or none are to be found, may elapse before they renppear in numbers.  Tis a rare run of luck, Pierre, said Cnmllle, one evening in January  If it holds, we shall have a fine freight for Fort CUimo when the ice goes out of the river. In April a serious mishap befell. For some time game had been growing scarce. Day after day the young men returned empty-handed to the cabin The furs already procured surpassed in value their expectations, but their sup ply of provisions was nearly exhausted and they were dependent in large measure for food on the result of their hunting. Except grouse and ptar migan, bird and beast alike had appar ently fled from that vicinity. Camille set out one forenoon to make the rounds of their longest line of traps which extended northwest in the same direction as the river. He expected to be gone two days. The route which i was Pierres turn to follow, and which lay in the opposite direction, was or dinariiy covered in half that time. Snow was falling when Pierre nr rived at the end of his line. Pereeiv lng that a severe storm was at hand he hurried homeward at his best pace, Presently a blizzard was roaring through the woods, and the driving snow-spray soon obscured the trail compelling the trapper to seek shelte In a rocky den amid thick clumps of spruce. There he remained a prlsone for forty-eight hours, suffering intense ly with hunger, thirst and cold, befor an Intermission in the gale permitted him to proceed to the cabin. Camille was not there! Filled with anxiety, Pierre was pr paring to search for his comrade, when he was again storm-bound. It was not until five dnys had elapsed since Camilles departure that Pier! was enabled to start on his errand . relief. But bis quest proved futile, No trace of his missing partner could he find. Stormy weather prevailed almost con tinually throughout April, keepin Pierre indoors much of the time. Nev before in his twenty-four years had In activity proved so hard to bear. T! sorting and packing of furs furnish some occupation, but this done, the hours dragged heavily. But except for an occasional pain in ills forehead, no premonitory symptoms heralded the singular affliction that impended. One evening, shortly before the ice in the river broke up, Pierre was cut ting spruce for fuel near the door of his cabin. The sun had just dropped behind the bald lulls to southwestward, when, as he stood with ax uplifted, something seemed to pass swiftly be fore ids eyes, blotting out the waning daylight.  Bewildered, lie let ids ax fall, and drew ids band across his face, then blinked and pereed about. Darkness eneompased him. He was blind, ut terly blind. In fear and trembling, Pierre groped his way into the cabin and threw him self despairingly upon the bales of furs piled beside his bunk. Then, gradually taking heart, he tried to comfort himself with the hope that his misfortune would prove to be only temporary.  It is the night-blindness! he cried. It will pass away with the dawn. He recalled cases, one of which he had himself witnessed, where others had been afflicted with that peculiar loss of sight which the voyageurs of the north term night blindness. By day, the vision of those who suffer with the malady is seemingly unim paired, but when deprived of sunlight they immediately become absolutely powerless to see. Some maintain that the same conditions which produce that dread scourge of high latitudes, scurvy, are also responsible for this curious visual trouble but whether it is scor butic or not, its origin has yet to be satisfactorily explained. To poor Pierre, awaiting in deepest anxiety the dawn which was to reveal whether or not his sight was perma nently lost, that night seemed infinitely long. Supperless, he crept Into his bunk, where he tossed hour after hour, starting up nervously at every sound. Once he fancied he heard Camilles voice, but when he strained his ears to listen, there was only the whisper ing of the wind. A pair of smoke-colored Labrador jays, chattering hungrily as they flut tered about the cabin, roused him. g his eyes, he sprang from his y. His sight Opc bunk with a loud cry was restored! Xt was broad day.

The result of the trip will be that a recom mendation will be made that owners north of the courthouse be permitted to ship their cattle to the protected districts after securing a certificate from the vet erinarian that the stock is not infected. This virtually takes about one-third of Campbell county out of the prohibited district and will probably destroy Lynch burg as a market for beef cattle from counties in the quarantine.  Charles Cook, 30 years old, of Nor folk, has a dangerous knife wound in his side and is expected to die. The wound is alleged to have been inflicted by Frank Grubb, 21 years of age, who has not been arrested. J. S. Grubb, the father of the young man, has been ar rested and is held under a bond of 500 for his appearance because he is charged with advising his son to flee. The wound was, it is said, inflicted during a quarrel between the young men, growing out of an old grudge be tween them. Robert Moore and Miss Messick, of Crittenden, a small village about 18 miles from Suffolk, eloped to North Caro lina and were married. Tlie bride is 14 years old and wore short dresses. She left her home in such a hurry that she did not get her hat and was without it for 40 miles which the couple drove. When they returned to Suffolk the husband took his bride to a dry goods store, where a trousseau was purchased. Mr. T. A. Jones, of Norfolk, who was graduated from the Virginia Military Institute in 1898 , has been selected by Gen. Scott Shipp, superintendent, to fill temporarily the vacancy in the faculty oc casioned by the resignation of Col. Rob ert A. Marr, professor of. engineering. Mr. Jones was graduated with honors in his class, and he is now employed as an assistant engineer on the Sea board Railway. The appointment is only for one year, pending the election by the board of visitors next June. Mr. Allan Talbott was appointed Dep uty Collector of Internal Revenue at Richmond, to succeed Robert McCan- dish, removed. Mr. Talbot held a simi lar position under the late Collector Brady, and is appointed upon merit. Miss Minnie Morrison Supinger, daughter of Mr. S. B. Supinger, of Sum- nierd, Rockbridge county, was married to Mr. William Bryon oilman in Elli ott Hill Methodist Church. Rev. Dr. A. G. Buckner, pastor of Falling Springs Presbyterian Church, officiated. Miss Kate Supinger, sister of the bride, was maid of honor and Mr. J. R. Supinger was best man. Rev. T. B. Southall, of McDowell, Va., has accepted the call extended to him by the Lexington Presbyterian congre gation, to succeed Rev. Dr. Thornton Whaling, who resigned to go to Texas. The new pastor will begin his pastorate October 20 . The police of Lynchburg are looking for Frank H. Gibson, who gave Rich mond as his residence and left Lynch burg several days ago, leaving a board bill unpaid for himself and wife. Since Gibson left the city it has transpired that he widely advertised in the large cities of the West an alleged matrimonial bu reau, in which he offered for sale the names of too pretty Southern girls who desired to be married. It is not improb able that the postal authorities will be asked to endeavor to locate the head of the alleged bureau. A warrant was is sued for his arrest some days ago. There were two ugly stabs on the right side and a pistol wound on the left shoulder. The theory is that Williams was murdered and placed on the railroad track by his as sailant. So far no arrests have been made. Charles Lowery, charged with beating Rachel Winter, 2 years and 6 months old, was held for trial as to insanity at Norfolk. The pretty little girl, who was brought to court to show the bruises on her face, could not tell her name. Dr. J. G. Riddick testified that he had cured Lowery of the morphine habit, but now he is a cocaine fiend. W. L. Tyler, of Portsmouth, a lamp trimmer employed by the Electric Light Company, was shocked to death and his body was found at the foot of the pole where he fell. The light was burn ing badly, and he climbed the pole to adjust it and touched a live wire in the darkness. He was 26 years of age, and leaves a widow and one child. He was i native of Richmond, but had lived in Portsmouth for several years. Robert Vance, mad with jealousy, dragged his wife from a construction car on the Norfolk and Western Rail way, near Abingdon, where she had taken refuge front rain in a car occu pied by men, and beat her so badly that she is expected to die. He clubbed her again and again until she was covered with blood. Probably she would have been killed except for the railroad hands, who dragged the husband from the helpless woman. Vance was given a hearing and sent on to the grand jury. Judge Scott, of the Circuit Court. Richmond, issued an order changing the name of William Dandridge Alexan der Anderson, son of the Attorney-Gen eral and a lieutenant in the United States Army. document.text: Domestic. In the municipal elections in Havana the Nationalists claim the election of their candidate for mayor and the ma jority of the Council. The Nationalists won also in other places. Mr. Bryan gave out a statement in Lincoln, Neb., in which he attacks the Supreme Court decision in the insular cases, and calls upon the people to re pudiate the verdict. The Chicago grand jury refused to find indictments against Dowie and the other Zionists accused of causing the death of Mrs. Judd and her child. A little son of John Williams, of Richmond, Va., got his head into an ice cream freezer, and it required two plumbers and a doctor to get it out. Five or six hundred soldiers started a riot in the saloon district about the Presidio, near San Francisco, and wreck ed one of the saloons. Floyd Blackburn, the clerk of the Richmond School Board, w10 stole 84 from the school funds, got 60 days on each of two charges. The reformed Presbyterian Synod of America, in session in Pittsburg, Pa., denounced labor unions, as well as secret societies. It is reported that a company has been organized with a capital of 3,000,000. to build a shipbuilding plant at Chester, Pa. William Gallagher and a little child were killed by falling down the shaft of an apartment house in Jersey City. Joseph Harris was arrested at Ann Arbor. Mich., cn the charge of kidnap ping Albert Koskea, aged 14. Two sections of Buffalo Bills train collided at Bellwood, Pa., wrecking six cars. Reports to machinists headquarters in Washington show that many men jn the shops of the Southern Railway in Southern cities are on strike. The gen eral strike of machinists declared in Chicago will, it is claimed, involve over 20.000 men. The Hall of Fame was dedicated at the University of the City of New York, where the tablets to the memory of the 29 American immortals were un veiled. Senator Chauncey Depew de livering the oration. The monument erected at Freder icksburg. Va.. by Gen. Daniel Butter field to the soldiers of the Fifth Army Corps, which he commanded, was dedi cated with interesting exercises. A rowboat containing a pleasure party went over a dam in the Schuyl kill river, near Philadelphia, and five girls and two boys were drowned. Lincoln J. McCarty, aged 68 years, of Lexington. Ky.. died apparently of hydrophobia, having predicted his de.v.h three days before the time. A l monument to the soldiers of the Civil War was unveiled at Battle Creek, Mich., Senator Julius Burrows and General Otis being present. Thomas B. Spellman was acquitted in Winchester, Va., of the charge of setting fire to the Old Dominion Paper Companys plant. The tugboat Acorn, in a fog. struck the coal piers at Kenova, W. Va., and wrecked the entire fleet of eight coal barges. Rev. J. Preston Lewis shot Lewis Hunt, colored, who had found the preachers coat on a fence -and was ex amining it. - Minister Wu, of China, delivered the oration at the ceremonies at Grants tomb in New York. - Blakely Hall, Sr., died at his home in New Brunswick, N. J., from blood poi soning. Sidney Cole was indicted in Parkers burg for the murder of Capt. W. T. Terry. .  The General Assembly of the Unied Presbyterian Church, in session at Des Moines, Iowa, passed a resolution ex- ciuding members of secret societies from church membership.

German forces have made a further advance on ths Russian fortress of Grodno, the only ine of their fortified positions near the German border which still re mains in their possession. Official an nouncement was made here of the cap ture of Lipsk, in northern Russian Poland, about 20 miles to the west of Grodno. The statement follows There are no special incidents to report from the western theater of war. Eastern theater Army group of Field Marshal Von Hindenburg The troops of General Von Bessler are sta tioned in tne region surrounding the bridge head south of Freidrlchstadt In an engagement east of the Nlemen the army of General Von Elchhorn reached a point northeast of Olita- An additional 1,600 prisoners and seven cannon were captured. In the direc tion of Grodno the town of Lipsk, on the Bohr River, was taken by storm and the enemy forced to surrender. The Widra, a tributary of the Sukelka, was crossed by our troops. The east ern border of the forest directly east of Dialystok has been reached at sev eral points. Army group of Prince Leopold In the Bielobiezh forest fighting goes on for possession of tne crossing over the upper Narcw. German and Austro- Hungarian troops under General Von Woyrsch drove the enemy out of his position at Suchodol, on the eastern border of the forest, and at Szereszowo and are now closely pursuing him. Army group of Field Marshal Von Mackensen In order to render pos sible the retreat of their rear-guard divisions through the marsh district, the Russians made a stand once mors on a line in the Koddubno district, south of Kobrin. They were defeated, although they brought back and threw into the battle some divisions which previously had been falling back.

document.text: B u c k i n g h a m .  Died at her home in Buckingham County in the 52nd, year of her age after a long and suffering illti-ss from the terrible affliction of cancer, Mrs. Jno. A. Burks duaghtcr of William Crews. , Mrs. Burks died a most triumphant death. Just as she was passing over the river she gave utterance to words that leave behind her the blissful assuranc that all was well with her soul. Her last words were open the door the Saviour has come. She was a consistent mem ber of Maple Grove Baptist church. She leaves behind her the husband, four daughters and five sons to mourn the loss of her. Blessed are the dead which die in the Lord. Yea, they do rest from their labor, and verily, their works do follow them. We are sorry to report the contin ued and unimproved lllneSB of Mr, J. B, Gilliam. Tha Drs. however give strong hope ot Mr. Gilliams case.- The speciul microscopist who has examined into and reported on Mr. Gilliams case does not report discourugingly at all. The Road Board meets today under tte new order of things brought about by the special .act concerning the roads of Buckingham. The sole management of the roads of the county now is in the hands of the Board of Supervisors. Each member is supposed to look after the roads of his district. Anything in reason for good roads. Bucking ham needs them as badly as any county and it is a thing that any county can ill afford to do without. Would that our people could be thoroughly aroused on this extreme ly important matter. Mr. Eddie Glover left for his home near Andersonville on Saturday, feeling very much indisposed and as he did not return to his place of business with Mr. A. C. Garnett, Jr. on Monday morning it is feared that he is still ery much indisposed. There are no new developments in the now very important Forbes burning case. Old Mr. Forbes is still very ill with chances for recovery very much against, him. The sym pathy and the -incere admiration of the thinking public of the entire county is with Miss Janie Forbes, the brave, noble and selfsacrificing daughter, who underwent such a terrible ordeal on the night of the burning. After parsing through such a trial of soul and body she on that memorable morning gave utter ance to a suggestion to the old color ed woman who was her only compan ion, save her helpless father, that will live in the memory of the people of the county to the credit of Miss Janie when her body will sleep in the dust Aunt Nancy,the birds are singing let us sing too. Can there be evil in the heart that could give expression to such sentiment as these? nay verily. Misses Lillie and Nannie Gilliam are on a visit to the home of Mr. A. C. Garnett, Jr. We are glad to see Miss Nannie so much improved iu health. Rev. Mr. Sanford preached a very fine sermon on the text she hath done what she could, to a small congregation at the Maysvills Baptist Church last night. He evidently gave the members of his church something to think of. And tbe injunction he gave to his members were equally applicable to members of other churches, who were present. We love to here Bro. Sanford. Mry he preach to us long and often. 1 close this letter while the snow is falling. I hope it is the last one of a severely cold winter. Merited success to the T iues . Q uoit . March 28th. 1904.
